articles.headline: Campus Protests Over Gaza Intensify Amid Pushback by Universities and Police
articles.snippet: There were more than 120 new arrests as universities moved to prevent pro-Palestinian encampments from taking hold as they have at Columbia University.
articles.abstract: There were more than 120 new arrests as universities moved to prevent pro-Palestinian encampments from taking hold as they have at Columbia University.
articles.lead_paragraph: A wave of pro-Palestinian protests spread and intensified on Wednesday as students gathered on campuses around the country, in some cases facing off with the police, in a widening showdown over campus speech and the war in Gaza.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman, David Montgomery, Jonathan Wolfe and Jenna Russell

articles.headline: Arizona Charges Giuliani and Other Trump Allies in Election Interference Case
articles.snippet: Those charged included Boris Epshteyn, a top legal strategist for Donald Trump, and fake electors who acted on Mr. Trump’s behalf in Arizona after the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: Those charged included Boris Epshteyn, a top legal strategist for Donald Trump, and fake electors who acted on Mr. Trump’s behalf in Arizona after the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mark Meadows, and a number of others who advised Donald J. Trump during the 2020 election were indicted in Arizona on Wednesday, along with all of the fake electors who acted on Mr. Trump’s behalf there to try to keep him in power despite his loss in the state.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Europe’s Policymakers Get Ready to Lower Rates, Regardless of the Fed
articles.snippet: European Central Bank governors are highlighting cooler inflation as a sign the bank could cut interest rates before the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: European Central Bank governors are highlighting cooler inflation as a sign the bank could cut interest rates before the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe’s central bankers are trying to get out of the shadow of the United States.

articles.headline: ‘To the Future’: Saudi Arabia Spends Big to Become an A.I. Superpower
articles.snippet: The oil-rich kingdom is plowing money into glitzy events, computing power and artificial intelligence research, putting it in the middle of an escalating U.S.-China struggle for technological influence.
articles.abstract: The oil-rich kingdom is plowing money into glitzy events, computing power and artificial intelligence research, putting it in the middle of an escalating U.S.-China struggle for technological influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Monday morning last month, tech executives, engineers and sales representatives from Amazon, Google, TikTok and other companies endured a three-hour traffic jam as their cars crawled toward a mammoth conference at an event space in the desert, 50 miles outside Riyadh.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Losing a Foot Never Held Her Back, Until She Tried to Join the Military
articles.snippet: Amputees who try to join the U.S. armed forces are rejected, no matter how capable they are. Hannah Cvancara wants to change that.
articles.abstract: Amputees who try to join the U.S. armed forces are rejected, no matter how capable they are. Hannah Cvancara wants to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hannah Cvancara’s dream is to become a nurse in the military, and she has been trying to achieve that dream for more than a decade. But every time she applies, she gets rejected.

articles.headline: With New Salt and Sugar Limits, School Cafeterias Are ‘Cringing’
articles.snippet: Many parents and nutritionists applauded stricter federal regulations, but food companies say the changes could increase costs and waste.
articles.abstract: Many parents and nutritionists applauded stricter federal regulations, but food companies say the changes could increase costs and waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around 11:40 on a cool spring day in early April, students began to stream into the lunchroom at Haleyville High School in Alabama.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Audra Melton

articles.headline: How a Pirate-Clad Pastor Helped Ignite Trump Media’s Market Frenzy
articles.snippet: Chad Nedohin, a part-time pastor, is among the fans of Donald J. Trump who helped turn Trump Media into a meme stock with volatile prices.
articles.abstract: Chad Nedohin, a part-time pastor, is among the fans of Donald J. Trump who helped turn Trump Media into a meme stock with volatile prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: One afternoon last month, Chad Nedohin, a part-time pastor and die-hard supporter of Donald J. Trump, put on a pirate costume, set up his microphone and recited a prayer.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Conservative Justices Appear Poised to Rule Ex-Presidents Have Some Level of Immunity
articles.snippet: Such a ruling would probably send the case back to a lower court and could delay any trial until after the November election.
articles.abstract: Such a ruling would probably send the case back to a lower court and could delay any trial until after the November election.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority appeared ready on Thursday to rule that former presidents have some degree of immunity from criminal prosecution, a move that could further delay the criminal case against former President Donald J. Trump on charges that he plotted to subvert the 2020 election.

articles.headline: Juggling Campaign and Foreign Policy, Biden Sends Complicated Messages
articles.snippet: The president signed a bill that could ban TikTok even as his re-election team uses it to reach young voters. It was hardly the first internal disparity on matters around the globe.
articles.abstract: The president signed a bill that could ban TikTok even as his re-election team uses it to reach young voters. It was hardly the first internal disparity on matters around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden just signed a bill that could ban President Biden from using TikTok. But Mr. Biden plans to keep using TikTok until Mr. Biden’s new law forces Mr. Biden off it.

articles.headline: These Playing Cards Have an Extra Motive. Flushing Out Suspects.
articles.snippet: The 2,500 decks being issued to correctional facilities in southern Mississippi seek clues on missing persons and unsolved murders. Cold case cards sometimes bring useful tips to dormant investigations.
articles.abstract: The 2,500 decks being issued to correctional facilities in southern Mississippi seek clues on missing persons and unsolved murders. Cold case cards sometimes bring useful tips to dormant investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: People incarcerated in southern Mississippi have been receiving new sets of playing cards that they can use to pass the time, but the images on those cards are not of the typical jacks, queens and kings of other game sets. Instead, they feature people whose murders or disappearances have been unsolved for years.

articles.headline: U.S. Growth Slowed in First Quarter, but Inflation Remained a Bug
articles.snippet: Gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation, increased at a 1.6 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year.
articles.abstract: Gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation, increased at a 1.6 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy remained resilient early this year, with a strong job market fueling robust consumer spending. The trouble is that inflation was resilient, too.

articles.headline: Key Solar Panel Ingredient Is Made in the U.S.A. Again
articles.snippet: REC Silicon says it will soon start shipping polysilicon, which has come mostly from China, reviving a Washington State factory that shut down in 2019.
articles.abstract: REC Silicon says it will soon start shipping polysilicon, which has come mostly from China, reviving a Washington State factory that shut down in 2019.
articles.lead_paragraph: A factory in Moses Lake, Wash., that shut down in 2019 will soon resume shipping a critical ingredient used in most solar panels that for years has been made almost exclusively in China.
